body: Some of the neighbors had been heard to express the wish over the years that a divine hand would smite Yeung Sun Live Poultry. Clucking chickens went into its storefront. Dead ones came out, bound for Chinatown restaurants. So did blood, and entrails, and putrid odors that wafted past the fancy lofts and dark-wood bars of an up-and-coming
title: A Collapse At a Poultry Shop Exposes a Rift Among Neighbors

body: NOT long ago, Thomas Sullivan's beauty routine began and ended with Irish Spring. But as Mr. Sullivan, an entrepreneur, actor, film producer and restaurant owner, approached 40, he realized his livelihood might benefit from a bit more personal maintenance. ''I have to take advantage of any way I can to look, if not younger, healthy,'' said Mr.
title: SKIN DEEP; Men Change (Products Do, Too)

body: Most of us, while visiting the New York Transit Museum, will not care too much that in the 1930s large coiled tubes containing liquid carbon tetrachloride were used as fuses to protect the city's subway system from short circuits. Many of us approach this subject so lightly that we might think a label on an electrical contraption -- ''Edison
title: MUSEUM REVIEW; Stand Clear Of the Ghosts

body: Suzanne Hart, a 41-year-old executive at one of Manhattan's most prominent advertising firms, was stepping into the elevator of an 85-year-old Midtown office building around 10 a.m. Wednesday, just as she had every workday for the past four years, while fellow workers streamed into the mosaic-tiled lobby. Then, in an inexplicable instant, after Ms.
title: Elevator Pins Woman Between Floors in Midtown Office Building, Killing Her

body: St. Ann's Warehouse, the Brooklyn theater that has provided a home for highly regarded productions including ''Black Watch'' and ''Misterman,'' will itself continue to have a home in Dumbo, not far from its current location in that neighborhood. The theater said on Monday that it had signed a three-year lease for a new space at 29 Jay Street, where
title: ARTSBEAT; St. Ann's Warehouse Finds a New Home

body: ON Columbia Place in Brooklyn Heights, improbably sandwiched between a Sardinian restaurant and a brick-walled cafe, stands a landmark in the history of housing for the poor. Its name is Riverside Houses, and it was created by the 19th-century philanthropist and urban visionary Alfred Tredway White. This complex of 260 apartments, designed for
title: HABITATS | BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; A Building With a Heart of Gold

body: Leironica Hawkins recalls always having ''social problems, sensory issues and bouts of depression,'' while growing up in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, as well as behavioral tics like self-rocking and involuntary hand twitches. Finally, at age 28, she was given a diagnosis: Asperger's syndrome, a form of autism, for which she has never received
title: CHARACTER STUDY; She Finds Refuge in Art

body: BEFORE the Fendi baguette grew stale and Marc Jacobs Stam knockoffs were sold on Canal Street, a young woman in the city's creative fields might have considered a luxury bag a necessary investment. These days, thanks to the ascent of the humble cloth tote, she can save her shoe budget and still look, well, smart. ''I often only carry a tote,'' said
title: NOTICED; A Message On Every Arm

title: Holiday Music Across the Centuries to the City

title: Holiday Theater, in Three Flavors

body: Four color-coded varieties of juice boxes were lined up at the opening last week of Module R, a design store in Brooklyn filled with objects for people who can't leave well enough alone. Movable, swappable elements make up items like the Tetrad Flat Shelving system, assembled from combinations of five units ($1,465 for the configuration pictured),
title: CURRENTS | OPEN; Modular Design for Modern Times

body: Twenty-five years ago my husband and I moved to Brooklyn, lured by the promise of more space than we could afford in Manhattan. We loved our big, sunny apartment and its proximity to Prospect Park, but if we wanted to eat in a restaurant that was not a pizzeria, or see a movie whose protagonist was not a superhero, we had to return to our old
title: The Academy

body: There is a certain queasiness to be felt every time one enters Brooklyn Bridge Park -- a sense that the whole enterprise isn't quite morally tenable. The first two perfectly pristine phases of the park have been in operation for more than a year now. When the project is completed it will bring 76 acres of artful waterfront parkland to Dumbo and
title: BIG CITY; Economic Revival, Without the Fancy Cheese?

body: 'Fantasia on the Loose' On Sunday a striking blond celebrity with lots of curves will emerge from her New York home and languorously greet her many adoring young fans. It's not Scarlett Johansson. Meet Fantasia, the albino Burmese python at the Brooklyn Children's Museum. Unlike many famous New Yorkers, she'll allow her admirers to touch her and
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Frederico Farina, a creative director for fashion brands, recalls waking up every morning last summer in his 21st-floor apartment in Brooklyn Heights and gazing across the river at the new Frank Gehry-designed apartment tower in Lower Manhattan. Its rippled stainless-steel facade reflected the sun, making it shine like a beacon. ''One day, my
title: THE APPRAISAL; Living in a 76-Story Work of Art, and a Symbol of Rebirth

body: Huddled together on the reading rug of a prekindergarten classroom on the Upper West Side, three budding builders assembled a multilayered church with a Gothic arch. title: With Blocks, Educators Go Back To Basics

body: IT was the night before Thanksgiving, and the Witch Queen of New York was not stirring her brew or flying on her broom. Well, she did have her broom, but she was using it to sweep up the Pagan Center of New York, her headquarters in the Bronx, on Webster Avenue and 189th Street near Fordham University. ''Where the heck is that dustpan?'' said the
title: CHARACTER STUDY; The Witch Wears Silk Suits

body: Irwin Schneiderman, a lawyer and a philanthropic leader who guided the New York City Opera through a decade of ups and downs, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 88. title: Irwin Schneiderman Dies at 88; Guided the City Opera

But this hotel lobby is different. And not just because of its five glittering chandeliers or the three-story marblelike columns that
title: Free Lodging in Old-Brooklyn Elegance, Just for a Select Group

body: Nine blocks from the steel shadow of Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn, Gib Veconi circles Prospect Heights nightly in his 13-year-old Volvo wagon looking for a parking spot, like a buzzard scouring for a meal. Parking can be a blood sport in New York City, nowhere more so than along the crowded streets around the half-built Barclays Center in Downtown
title: Plan to Issue New Permits For Parking Is Debated

body: The buyer was looking for a town house in Brooklyn. It needed living space for a family of five and entertaining space for crowds in the dozens. title: THE APPRAISAL; Luring a New Headmaster With a $3.8 Million Town House

body: MALKA LUBELSKI marched for economic justice last Sunday dressed as Minnie Mouse. In a pink costume with white polka dots and black mouse ears, she circled Zuccotti Park, the epicenter of the Occupy Wall Street protests, carrying a homemade sign that read, ''From the very young, the very old, we are the 99%.'' title: For Children's Sake, Taking to the Streets

body: A Spare Times entry in some editions on Friday about the exhibition ''ElectriCity: Powering New York's Rails'' at the New York Transit Museum in Brooklyn Heights, using outdated information from the museum, misstated the opening date. It is Saturday; it did not open on Tuesday.

body: Q. We live in Westchester County, N.Y., and are excited to be hosting a couple from Sardinia whom we met on vacation there. They will be here at New Year's Eve time. It is their first visit to the United States, and they will be with us for four days. We are stymied trying to identify what New York City sights to focus on, since there are so many.
title: IN TRANSIT; Q&A: New Year's Eve Weekend in New York

body: 11:20 p.m. | Updated It is one of the more momentous tasks facing the Cuomo administration: turning around New York City's ailing mass transit system, the largest in the country. But on Thursday, in choosing the next head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo looked not to a transportation expert but to an accomplished
title: Cuomo Chooses Veteran of City's Politics, Not a Transit Expert, to Lead the M.T.A.

body: An article on Wednesday about a legal dispute over the sale of a home once owned by Norman Mailer misidentified the location where Mailer stabbed one of his wives, Adele. It occurred in their home on the Upper West Side, not in Brooklyn Heights.
title: Corrections

body: Norman Mailer's Brooklyn Heights apartment has seen its share of fighting. Mailer retired there after his notorious altercations with other literary heavyweights. Mailer died in 2007, his reputation as both a giant of American letters and a verbal pugilist secure. But even in death, the fighting continues, this time over the apartment itself.
title: True to Mailer's Life, a Brawl Over the Sale of His Brooklyn Heights Apartment

title: READER COMMENTS; In Bed for 19 Months, At Hospital's Expense

title: Music In Review

body: The pink slips have gone out, and if no deal is reached by Friday, 716 of New York City's lowest-paid workers -- school aides, parent coordinators and other members of school support staffs -- will lose their jobs, the latest victims of budget cuts to the public schools. Nearly 350 schools will be affected, in a scattered pattern, according to a
title: School Layoffs About to Fall Heaviest On the Poorest and Most Struggling

body: DURING the real estate boom, it seemed that every day brought news of a new condominium project in New York. title: New Condos: 'Survivor' Edition

body: Nearly five years ago, Steven M. Cohen, a federal prosecutor turned white-collar criminal defender, agreed to leave the courtroom and serve a two-year stint as the chief of staff for the state's newly elected attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo. After two years, he agreed to stay for the rest of Mr. Cuomo's term as attorney general. Then, last
title: Governor's Right-Hand Man Returns to Private Sector

body: As the Jehovah's Witnesses prepare to move their headquarters out of Brooklyn, where their Watchtower sign has long been a fixture of the cityscape, they are selling two town houses, two brownstones and a carriage house on prime Brooklyn Heights blocks. The five properties, with combined asking prices of $18.8 million, are going on the market this
title: BIG DEAL; Jehovah's Witnesses List Prime Properties

body: For decades, the intersection of Park Avenue and 96th Street has remained one of the city's most obvious and despairing emblems of disparity, with East Harlem and its challenges spreading out to the north, and a vast gridlock of extraordinary privilege colonizing the acreage below. It is worth debating whether a visit to this corner ought to be
title: BIG CITY; Steps Away, But Living Worlds Apart In the City

body: Brooklyn's latest historic district - a cluster of 21 skyscrapers and office buildings surrounding Borough Hall downtown - was created on Tuesday over the objections of some of its landowners and inhabitants. The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission approved the Borough Hall Skyscraper Historic District despite opposition from business groups
title: Historic District in Brooklyn Is Approved, Despite Outcry

author: Sharifa Rhodes-Pitts is the author of ''Harlem Is Nowhere: A Journey to the Mecca of Black America.''

title: Experimental City

body: THE pre-Civil War town house at 197 Amity Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that is home to Stan Stanford, Judith Albert and their four children has enjoyed two brushes with fame. One involved the television series ''Law & Order,'' whose producers briefly contemplated using the house for an episode involving a murder that takes place in a kitchen.
title: HABITATS | COBBLE HILL, BROOKLYN; House of Strings and Feathers

body: In the back of a locker in a firehouse in Brooklyn Heights, there is a portal through time. It takes the shape of a leather-bound firefighter's logbook, where usually the ruled paper is filled with the departure times of the company's fire trucks as they ferry crews out to emergency calls. This book is as nondescript as the dozens of other logbooks
title: THE 9/11 DECADE; 'Dear Firefighters...'

author: E-mail: sgf1@columbia.edu
body: Right on time for his 3 p.m. appointment, Sam Botwin climbed the stairs of Dave Hall's row house in Brooklyn, making his way to the rehearsal room on the second floor. There he stood at a makeshift lectern in his baggy shorts and floppy shirt and mop-top hair, a boy of 13, and began to read from a speech about the Jewish martyrs of Masada. Sam was
title: ON RELIGION; A Boy's Bar Mitzvah Lessons Bridge a Cultural Chasm

title: Spare Times: Around Town

body: 92ND STREET Y CHILDREN'S WARHOL FESTIVAL Andy Warhol's name immediately evokes images of soup cans and celebrities. But wind-up mice? Mechanical terriers? Choo-choo trains? title: Spare Times: For Children

body: In the beginning, there was Public School 1. Then it got messy. There are actually four P.S. 1's in New York City: That first school, established in 1806 and later named for Alfred E. title: Naming a Public School in New York? It Isn't as Simple as 1, 2, 3

title: FALL RESTAURANT PREVIEW; Fall's Bounty: Flavors From Home and Abroad

body: It was as if one huge new and very bad neighborhood appeared overnight in New York City. Zone A. This area, once housing sought-after properties with waterfront views, now deemed at risk of flooding, became blighted with red marks on a map -- from Battery Park to Coney Island to Staten Island's south beaches -- as Hurricane Irene approached with
title: New Yorkers Flee by Taxicab, Bus and Wet Feet, or Not at All

body: Miles has been going to Ace Bar all his life. His face has grayed there. Friends have come and gone. He never paid for a drink, but rarely walked out of the East Village bar with an empty stomach. He may have purged his dinner on the floor a time or two, his fellow bar patrons said, but who among them hadn't done the same? Over the past year,
title: As Bars Shut Doors To Dogs, a Tradition Ends

body: BEFORE the financial markets' most recent drubbing, New York City's real estate prices had been flat for the better part of a year. But over the spring and summer, prices in certain pockets of property sprinkled around Manhattan and Brooklyn had rebounded to or beyond pre-recession levels. These micromarkets could turn up along a particular avenue
title: Barely Missing A Beat

title: Spare Times

body: WINNIE-THE-POOH BIRTHDAY BASH Few 90-year-old celebrities can claim legions of fans under 12. Probably even fewer could sit unperturbed through a party with those clamorous admirers. title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's job approval rating among New Yorkers has hit its lowest point in six years, with residents conveying widespread anxieties about the city's economic prospects, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Nearly 70 percent of city residents characterize the economy as being bad. And New Yorkers are chiefly
title: Poll Finds Bloomberg's Approval Rating the Lowest in 6 Years

body: Stanley Bosworth, a self-described ''old wizard'' who shaped his own Hogwarts in Brooklyn in the form of Saint Ann's School, which rapidly gained national prominence for its free-form approach to education and its success in sending graduates to top colleges, died on Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 83. The cause was complications of
title: Stanley Bosworth, 83, Iconoclastic Head of Brooklyn School

author: E-mail: powellm@nytimes.com
body: This is how scandal rolls in our contracted-out age. Eight months ago, a deputy director at a city-financed job center leafed through work sheets and noticed something curious. title: Harry Bernstein, Late-Blooming Author, Dies at 101

title: Norman Mailer's Many-Sided Life, Seen Through His Home

title: The Man Who Made Workouts Cool

title: THE APPRAISAL; The Sounds Of Drummers, Handled Gingerly

title: In Age of Digital Music, Vinyl Gets Second Life In a Brooklyn Factory

body: George Tooker, a painter whose haunting images of trapped clerical workers and forbidding government offices expressed a peculiarly 20th-century brand of anxiety and alienation, died on Sunday at his home in Hartland, Vt. title: Burglars in Brooklyn Heights Find the Doors (and Windows) Are Open

''The Aging Brain: An Owners Manual'' is the first of three interactive courses exploring cognitive
title: Spare Times

author: Naima Coster, a writer, is earning her master's in English at Fordham University.
body: I HAVE always felt as if Brooklyn belonged to me. At the very least, Fort Greene was mine. While I was growing up in the late 1980s and the 1990s, Fort Greene was notorious for being a rough neighborhood, home to one of New York City's largest public housing projects. For most of my life, this provided me with incredible and undue street cred: I
title: NEW YORK STORY; Remembering When Brooklyn Was Mine

body: Around Town Museums and Sites American Museum of Natural History (Saturday and Wednesday) ''Saluting Our Jazz Elders,'' an afternoon of music and discussions on Saturday in celebration of Black History Month, will include performances by the percussionist Sekou Alaje (12:30 p.m.); the New Amsterdam Music Association (1:15 p.m.); the trumpet player
title: Spare Times

body: OPENING COLONIE The partners, who came from Public and Double Crown, used Kickstarter to help finance this Brooklyn Heights restaurant. The chef, Alex Sorenson, formerly of Mas (Farmhouse), cooks oysters Rockefeller, black risotto with crisp mushrooms and rabbit lasagna. One adventurous dessert: foie gras doughnuts. (Opens Thursday): 127 Atlantic
title: Off the Menu

body: THE Brooklyn Cruise Terminal on the Buttermilk Channel has picturesque views even when the Queen Mary 2, which docks there regularly, is at sea. There is verdant Governor's Island across the water and, behind it , the heaving, jagged rise of Manhattan. To the north are the great bridges of the East River. To the west, the Statue of Liberty. And to
title: 36 HOURS; Brooklyn

body: THOUGH Anne Bauso grew up in Middle Village, Queens, she was always fond of Brooklyn. Her parents were from Bushwick, and on Saturdays she went there with her father and brother, visiting the extended family and shopping for food in the Italian section of Knickerbocker Avenue. ''I had very warm feelings for Brooklyn from the start,'' she said. Ms.
title: THE HUNT; A Move in the Direction of 'More Life'

title: Spare Times

body: Do you really want to go with that same old candy-and-flowers routine this week? Here are some different takes on love that won't take it out on your credit card. On Saturday the singer-songwriter Tamar-kali and her sextet, the Psychochamber Ensemble, demonstrate love, desire, passion, infatuation and heartbreak through illusion, burlesque, aerial
title: Weekend Miser

body: A struggling Brooklyn hospital is making plans to shut down in March after a decision by the Cuomo administration to delay grants to help finance a merger intended to rescue the institution, officials said on Wednesday. The hospital, Long Island College Hospital, on the border of Cobble Hill and Brooklyn Heights, announced in October that it was
title: Delay of Money From State May Force Hospital to Shut

body: To the Editor: Your article of Jan. 30, ''A Lavish Lifestyle, and Now Renters, Too,'' describes some of the amenities of William Beaver House. But you failed to mention the greatest benefit to prospective renters. William Beaver House is the only building in New York City from which you are guaranteed that you cannot see the ugliest building in New
title: LETTERS; Unmentioned Luxury

author: E-mail: appraisal@nytimes.com
body: Archie Gottesman is a pet lover and the chairwoman of Animal Haven, a shelter for cats and dogs. She spends her spare time looking for homes for pets, to save them from being euthanized. She is also the chief executive of Edison Properties, which owns Manhattan Mini-Storage, a chain of parking garages, and a three-year-old rental building on the
title: THE APPRAISAL; Giving New Meaning to the Term 'a Fixer-Upper'

body: MICHAEL MOSHAN bought his first condo in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, in 2003. A few years later he persuaded his girlfriend, Shana Liebman, to move there from the West Village. She was skeptical -- she didn't want to be surrounded by 20-somethings just out of school. But over the years the neighborhood, with its restaurants, bars and galleries, grew on
title: Williamsburg, Toddlertown

body: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS STUDIO $365,000 BROOKLYN: 75 Henry Street (Pineapple Street), #9J A co-op with a foyer, a living/dining room, a sleeping alcove, a separate kitchen, three closets, and a shared storage room down the hall, in a midcentury high-rise with a common roof deck and landscaped grounds. Jenet Levy, Halstead (212) 381-4268; www.halstead.com
title: ON THE MARKET

body: Some people have speculated that a town house at 29 Grace Court in Brooklyn Heights on the market for $5.95 million is not selling because it is too pink. Granted, the walls, the ceiling and the window moldings in the enormous parlor of the four-family home are covered in a bright shade of bubble gum. And after the price was reduced from $6.2
title: Big Deal | A Tougher Sell in Brownstone Brooklyn

body: That the East Coast Chamber Orchestra, a conductorless string ensemble formed in 2001 and also known as ECCO, has not yet become a household name among classical music lovers is surely because it appears so infrequently. ''We all have other, real jobs,'' the violinist Nick Kendall said from the stage as he introduced the group at its Peoples'
title: MUSIC REVIEW; A String Ensemble at Play: Body Language and Sheer Exuberance

body: THE final noisemaker has squealed and the last dinner guest has straggled home, so the holiday extravaganza that is Christmas and New Year's -- spread out over two long weekends and punctuated by a blizzard -- is over.
